content.description: The graphs below show the energy output of one kilowatt of photovoltaic <math alttext="P V" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>PV</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> capacity of different <math alttext="P V" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> panel systems over a day (graph on the left) and the annual energy production (graph on the right) of the same systems. Dual-axis tracking means that the <math alttext="P V" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> panels are constantly moving to always face the Sun directly. If the <math alttext="P V" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> panels are tilted in a fixed position, the direction of tilt is indicated. Flat <math alttext="P V" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> panels are not tilted in any direction.
content.question: Which of the following statements is best supported by the data shown in the graph?

choices.label: <math alttext="P V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> panels that cannot track the Sun and are in a fixed position tilted to the east produce the most electricity daily and annually.

Of the <math alttext="P V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> panels that cannot track the Sun, those in a fixed position tilted to the west produce more electricity daily and annually than do those in a fixed position tilted to the south.

<math alttext="P V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> panels that cannot track the Sun and are in a fixed position tilted to the south produce the least electricity daily and annually.

<math alttext="P V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> panels that can track the Sun and are constantly moving to always directly face the Sun produce the most electricity daily and annually.

content.answer: <math alttext="P V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> panels that can track the Sun and are constantly moving to always directly face the Sun produce the most electricity daily and annually.

skill.text: Skill 5.C: Explain patterns and trends in data to draw conclusions.
